name: Vitamin C (Ascorbic Acid)
summary: Vitamin C, or ascorbic acid, is an essential water-soluble vitamin with antioxidant properties, important for collagen synthesis, immune function, iron absorption, and wound healing. Severe deficiency causes scurvy.
description: Vitamin C is a potent antioxidant and enzymatic cofactor involved in hydroxylation reactions. It is critical for collagen production, neurotransmitter synthesis, and immune defense. Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C, requiring dietary intake from fruits and vegetables. Deficiency results in scurvy, with symptoms including bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, and anemia. Beyond deficiency prevention, vitamin C is widely studied for its role in immunity, skin health, cardiovascular protection, and as an adjunctive therapy in infections and cancer.

metadata.natural_source: Citrus fruits, strawberries, kiwi, bell peppers, broccoli, tomatoes

primary_indications: Adjunct to improve iron absorption in anemia
off_label_uses: Adjunctive therapy in infections (e.g., colds, sepsis)
High-dose IV vitamin C in oncology (experimental)
contraindications: Caution in patients with history of kidney stones (oxalate stones)
Caution in G6PD deficiency (risk of hemolysis with high doses)
monitoring_required: Kidney function in high-dose IV use
Oxalate levels if prolonged high-dose therapy

items: Treatment and prevention of vitamin C deficiency (scurvy)
Adjunct in wound healing and postoperative recovery

sections.text: Vitamin C functions as a reducing agent and antioxidant, regenerating other antioxidants such as vitamin E. It serves as a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases in collagen synthesis, dopamine β-hydroxylase in catecholamine synthesis, and enzymes in carnitine biosynthesis. Its antioxidant properties help protect against oxidative stress and support immune cell function.

adult.deficiency: 300–1000 mg/day in divided doses until recovery
adult.IV high-dose: 10–100 g/day (experimental oncology use under medical supervision)

sections.pediatric: Varies by age (15–75 mg/day RDA); deficiency treated with higher doses as directed

sections.text: Improvement in scurvy symptoms occurs within days; full recovery within 1–2 weeks. Antioxidant and immune effects may require sustained use.

serious: Hemolysis in G6PD deficiency (rare, high doses)

other: Excess intake can lead to gastrointestinal upset and kidney stones.
Use caution in patients with renal impairment or G6PD deficiency.

items.action: Beneficial but monitor for iron overload in hemochromatosis
Avoid high-dose unless directed by oncologist

sections.pregnancy: Safe at RDA doses; avoid high doses
sections.pediatrics: Safe within RDA; deficiency must be treated
sections.geriatrics: Safe; may have increased need due to dietary gaps

sections.text: Not required; discontinuation is safe, though deficiency may develop with prolonged inadequate intake.

items: Scurvy is rare in developed countries but can occur in malnourished, elderly, or alcohol-dependent individuals.
Vitamin C supplementation may slightly reduce duration of colds but does not prevent them in the general population.
High-dose IV vitamin C is under investigation in oncology and critical illness, but evidence is limited.
